intro: Lobanilia bakeriana, commonly known as the Baker's lobanilia, is a rare and lesser-known plant species native to the high altitudes of the Andes. It is a flowering plant belonging to the family Polygonaceae, characterized by its erect stems and basal leaves. The plant produces small, clustered flowers that are typically greenish-white in color, which bloom during the cooler months. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires a cool, moist environment to flourish. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a sensitive indicator of ecological health in its native region.
